Here's the thing about Taylor Swift. Why she wins all the time and it took so long for so many to really understand the depth of her. And now it seems like the world is falling over to sing her praises where it had previously had dismissiveness.Make no mistake that Taylor Swift is ruthlessly intelligent. She is smarter than you. It's not some brag central to her identity, she just is, because it's not. She's been on this path since she was a very child.What people leave out about Taylor being a nepobaby is that her parents were investment bankers. They did not need money. They did not need to craft her into a breadwinner.No. They are very intelligent people. And at the age of 12, Taylor Swift had convinced her parents they should MOVE THEIR ENTIRE LIFE to foster her promise. They invested in what was in front of them. They did not make Taylor Swift. They were smart enough to know this child was... what the fuck, something more than them. Enough to sell a fucking house. To demo tapes to record labels. What the fuck. üßµ

item.title: Catrina Hacker
item.description: I've spent a lot of time over the last couple years thinking about #sciComm, both in sharing research with the public and other scientists. Doing research for my latest Penn NeuroKnow post debunking common myths about the brain was fascinating as I traced through where several of these myths originated. Oftentimes they start with real #neuroscience results that get twisted into something overly generalized or not quite accurate. In some cases, as with the "tongue map" myth, we have a pretty clear idea of what single decision or moment in time caused the confusion, but in other cases it's less clear how we got to such widespread misconceptions. In my post I briefly talked about how anyone can help stop this cycle of miscommunication, but I'm eager to hear other opinions about where the responsibility to prevent future neuromyths lies and what we as neuroscientists can do to stop them.You can read my post, "Neuro MythBusters: The truth behind 10 common myths about your brain", here: https://pennneuroknow.com/2023/09/05/neuro-mythbusters-the-truth-behind-10-common-myths-about-your-brain/

item.title: Yogi Jaeger
item.description: #introduction post:I was trained as a systems biologist, running an empirical research group working on the evolution of gene regulatory networks in Barcelona up until 2015. I then turned to more philosophical questions, especially the role of organismic agency in evolution, and its relation to "artificial intelligence," which should instead be called "algorithmic mimicry."Today, I'm trying to build a new metamodern science for the coming post-abundance age.https://www.johannesjaeger.eu
